page.title: 14FILKINS: BUILDINGS (cont)
page.content: They have an internal chimney breast & circular stair and were built by masons for themselves on waste ground- tightly packed so there was little space for sanitation or veg patch, and usually with a thatched roof. The 18TH CENTURY brought 13 small houses (two have been inns), 1 small farmhouse and 1 large farmhouse associated with the 'model' farmyard now converted for small indus- try. The VICTORIAN YEARS brought a chu- rch by the architect George Street, a Men's Reading Room, a Church School & Schoolhouse, and a Wesleyan Chapel. In the 20TH CENTURY many 'slum' cottages were razed and 38 Council Houses were built. The first four, Saxons' Close, were built in 1937 by Sir Stafford Cripps in vernacular materials to a good design by architect Morley Horder- the first council houses listed for their social and historical importance.
